diamond_metaphor.explanation: A Diamond has many Facets, or Faces, which the Light may move through in different ways. A Diamond, in order to become what we Symbolically know it as, must begin as a rough Stone, and that Stone must be Destroyed, yet Preserved, in order to Create the Symbolic 'Diamond' form.
diamond_metaphor.application: You can extrapolate this into any Art-form: things are 'Destroyed' from their Natural state, to create a form suitable to Humans, and then used for formal 'Creation.' The Creative force called 'Destruction' is called the God Shiva.

pashupati.title: Lord of Animals
pashupati.origin: Ancient Indus Valley Civilization, dating back over 4,500 years
pashupati.archaeology: Seals from Mohenjo-Daro depicting a horned figure seated in yogic posture, surrounded by animals—earliest known representation of what would become Shiva
pashupati.connections: Later became the Greek God Pan, and the Hindu God Shiva; but in Hinduism, Pashupati is still acknowledged as an existent form of Shiva
pashupati.significance: The most ancient God to be Worshiped in an unbroken Chronological chain on a large scale
pashupati.modern_temple: Pashupatinath Temple in Kathmandu, Nepal, has stood for fifteen centuries and ranks as one of the holiest shrines to Shiva

rudra.title: The Roarer
meanings: The God Who Plays With Poisons and Cures
rudra.dual_nature: The God who brings Sickness when it comes, but also the God you pray to in order to remove the Sickness
rudra.scripture: The Rig Veda contains the Sri Rudram, one of the oldest liturgies in human history
rudra.principle: The same force which destroys is the force which liberates

third_eye.title: The Third Eye: Eternal Vigilance
third_eye.story: Parvati one day covered Shiva's Eyes playfully, and a Third Eye opened on his forehead, because if the Supreme Lord God Shiva is ever not vigilant over the Universe, it will fall into Chaos.
symbolism: The eye that sees beyond physical reality
Associated with the pineal gland, recognized as the seat of higher consciousness
third_eye.power: When Shiva opens His Third Eye, it can destroy ignorance—or, when directed outward in wrath, it can destroy creation itself

burning_of_desire.title: Shiva and Kamadeva
burning_of_desire.story: Shiva was Meditating, and Eros (Kamadeva in India, Cupid in Europe) shot an Arrow at Shiva. Instead of opening his physical Eyes, his Third Eye opened and Burned Eros to ash.
burning_of_desire.meaning: Shiva overcoming Desire, being more Powerful than Desire
burning_of_desire.teaching: Attachment and craving are obstacles to liberation. Yet Parvati's devotion eventually draws Him into marriage, showing that divine love transcends mere desire.

neelkanth.title: The Drinking of Poison
neelkanth.context: Samudra Manthan - the great churning of the cosmic ocean
neelkanth.story: When Halahala, the most lethal poison in the universe emerged, Lord Shiva drank the poison to save everyone. Parvati pressed her hands upon His throat to prevent the poison from descending, and it remained there, turning His throat blue.
neelkanth.cannabis_connection: To cool His burning throat, the gods offered Him Bhang—cannabis prepared as a cooling drink. This is one of the origins of Shiva's association with cannabis.
neelkanth.parallel: An act of supreme compassion similar to the Crucifixion of Jesus

shiva_and_kali.title: The End of Destruction
shiva_and_kali.kali_origin: A form of Shiva's Wife, comes from Parvati's mouth as a Dark Cloud when she is Angry
shiva_and_kali.kali_nature: The Goddess of Death and Cremation, representing time itself (Kala) and the inevitable end of all things
shiva_and_kali.story: Kali was on a rampage threatening to destroy creation. Shiva lay beneath Kali's feet, saying she would have to kill him too. And she stopped.
shiva_and_kali.iconography: Kali standing upon Shiva's chest, tongue extended in shock
meanings: Even the most destructive forces can be calmed by love
The masculine and feminine principles are eternally intertwined

part_3_nataraja.title: Shiva Nataraja — The Lord of Dance
part_3_nataraja.description: Shiva is the force that makes you Dance. As Nataraja, He performs the Tandava, the cosmic dance that creates, maintains, and destroys the universe in an eternal cycle.

symbolism.upper_right_hand: Holds the damaru (drum) - rhythm of creation and the sound of AUM from which the universe emerged
symbolism.lower_right_hand: Raised in Abhaya mudra - gesturing 'fear not'
symbolism.lower_left_hand: Points to His raised foot - indicating liberation
symbolism.standing_upon: Apasmara, the demon of ignorance and forgetfulness - enlightenment requires conquering one's own unconsciousness
symbolism.ring_of_flames: The eternal cycle of creation and destruction

cern_connection.fact: A replica of the Nataraja statue stands at CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research
cern_connection.reason: Physicists recognized in this ancient symbol a perfect representation of the dance of subatomic particles—the constant creation and destruction occurring at the most fundamental level of reality
cern_connection.quote_source: Fritjof Capra: the metaphor of the cosmic dance unifies ancient mythology and modern physics

atharva_veda.quote: To the five kingdoms of the plants which Soma rules as Lord we speak. Darbha, hemp, barley, mighty power: may these deliver us from woe.
atharva_veda.additional: The Atharva Veda mentions cannabis as one of the 'five sacred plants... which release us from anxiety' and states that a guardian angel resides in its leaves

scriptural_foundations.vedic_description: The Vedas call cannabis a source of happiness, joy-giver, liberator that was compassionately given to humans to help us attain delight and lose fear

legend_of_discovery.version_1: Shiva once had an argument with his family and wandered into the fields. Drained from conflict and sun, He fell asleep under a leafy plant. Upon waking, He sampled the leaves and was instantly rejuvenated. He made the plant His favorite food.
legend_of_discovery.version_2: After drinking the Halahala poison during Samudra Manthan, Shiva was given Bhang to cool His burning throat. Some texts say a drop of nectar fell on Mount Mandara and turned into a plant whose leaves were crushed to make Bhang. Lord Shiva brought the plant down to the Himalayas for humanity.

bhang.description: The mildest preparation, made from leaves and seeds
bhang.consumption: Typically consumed as a drink mixed with milk, spices, and sweeteners (Bhang Thandai)
bhang.use: Most commonly used during religious festivals

ganja.description: Made from flowering tops of female plant
ganja.consumption: Typically smoked in a chillum (clay pipe)

charas.description: The strongest preparation, similar to hashish
charas.source: Made from the resin of the cannabis plant
charas.use: Generally reserved for sadhus and holy men who dedicate their lives to ascetic practice

sadhus_and_maha_shivaratri.festival: Maha Shivaratri - the Great Night of Shiva
sadhus_and_maha_shivaratri.attendance: Approximately 100,000 Hindus gather near temples like Pashupatinath in Nepal
sadhus_and_maha_shivaratri.sadhu_quote_1: Shiva loves marijuana. So we come to share Shiva's prasad [offerings] with everyone else.
sadhus_and_maha_shivaratri.sadhu_quote_2: That [smoking marijuana] makes us forget everything and we communicate with Shiva. The cannabis helps stave off worldly desires.
sadhus_and_maha_shivaratri.legal_note: Nepal lifts its cannabis ban every year for this festival; in many parts of India, government-authorized shops prepare Bhang Thandai during Maha Shivaratri and Holi
sadhus_and_maha_shivaratri.naga_babas_aghoris: Consume bhang daily to imitate Lord Shiva's path to salvation. Cover their faces and bodies with ash and retreat to remote caves for years to meditate. Leave the Himalayas only for Maha Kumbh Mela every 12 years.

chemistry_as_shivas_work.principle: Destruction, and all forms of Creation, are best represented in what is now called 'Chemistry,' and in what was previously Alchemy
chemistry_as_shivas_work.explanation: In Chemistry, things form New things; that is what Chemistry is. Shiva is simply a force of Nature and cannot be denied. The transformation of matter, the breaking of bonds and forming of new bonds, the endless dance of molecules—this is the Tandava occurring at the molecular level.

conclusion.title: Shiva Is Coming to America
statements: Shiva is what happens when you smoke Marijuana.
Shiva is what happens when you Dance.
Shiva is simply a force of Nature and cannot be denied.
conclusion.synthesis: For thousands of years, from the Indus Valley to the temples of Nepal, from the sadhus in the Himalayas to the scientists at CERN, humanity has sought to understand the force of transformation—the creative destruction that makes all change possible. This force has been called Pashupati, Rudra, Shiva.
conclusion.invitation: Now this ancient tradition comes to America, not as something foreign, but as the recognition of a truth that has always been present: that destruction and creation are one process, that chemistry is sacred, that consciousness can be explored and expanded, and that the Lord of Bhang invites all sincere seekers to share in His prasad.
